The issue template usually contains more blanks than necessary to describe the problem¡ªfor example, the "expected behavior/actual behavior" is very often duplicated from the "overall description" for straightforward bugs. This makes the issue report more verbose than it should be.
column14: Right now, we've ported our issue templates to issue forms, which work great. I hope that GitHub can offer non-editable Markdown that's copied to the final report. Right now, only the headings are filled in.
column15: Even with a template, it can still be extremely poorly filled, or sections are completely ignored or filled with irrelevant sentences. At the end of the day, it still depends on the issue submitter's own discretion.

column14: Issues mentioned with remaining timeline to make fast paced environment.

column12: Reassure even experienced contributors that we have not forgot anything in the issue report.  Templates are not just for novices. I am a contributor who works on multiple projects which use different processes and different systems. Even when I have used a particular project's process and system before, it is reassuring to have a template, so that I can be confident I am remembering the right process and data fields. I do not want to accidentally apply the process and data fields from a different project.
column13: Most of the projects I work with are not using issue or PR templates. Many projects, even those who publish code on Github, host their bug database or ticket system someplace other than Github.   For projects which do use issue/PR templates, it raises the threshold of minimum work required to report an issue. It is harder to make a minimal report just so that the issue is not forgotten, to be followed later by the rest of the details.
column14: No comment
column15: I have not used Github's issue/PR templates enough to have something useful to say.  There are other kinds of template. For instance, the MacPorts project has a chapter in their user guide documentation listing how to file an issue report, field by field and step by step. I use this with every report, and keep finding it useful even after I have filed several reports. See https://guide.macports.org/#project.tickets .

column12: Generally I do agree they may help in some cases but in 99% of the situations they just turn what could be a simple contribution into a chore, filled with information thats probably not needed.
column13: If the project is important to me then I will put the time in to do the detailed report but often time it just turns it into a big chore to report a simple thing. I have abandoned submitting issues before when I was busy working and just wanted to point out a simple issue with a project for them to investigate but they wanted a long template filling out with screenshots and versions and all sorts.
column14: Simpler initial reporting with a follow up template if the developers need it.
column15: The worst thing is when you make great contributions and the pr or issue just gets ignored. column13: Once templates are added, it puts an additional burden on us to make sure there are templates for all situations. We do not want to discourage new contributors simply because we have not added templates for certain situations.

column14: standardization of templates across forges (GitHub, Gitlab, Gitea, etc)

column13: Often bug reporters do not read the template at all or understand the issue format, so they either submit a blank issue, write the entire issue description in the title, or fill the template with gibberish.   Other times the template may contain instructions that may not be easily understood by some bug reporters, or are too long to fit inside their attention span.
column14: Recommend (but don't enforce) a limit on the length of each instruction. Set up a form field interface so new contributors more easily understand that the template has various sections that need to be filled.

column13: It is sometimes hard to get the expected information, not even being sure it is relevant. It is definitely more work, no matter the size and impact of the PR (for example, for fixing some typos in the documentation, most information are irrelevant, except the commit itself).
column14: Some automatization would definitely help. For example, if the tool is capable of detecting unit tests in the PR, it could not show this item to the contributor (or automatically check a check box, or whatever automatization could be done).
